title: When should a midsize town hold its holiday reading?
vignette: Smaller villages sometimes recite the annual commemorative scroll on the weekly market day so farmers are present. A growing town now meets the population threshold of a regular municipality. Should it keep reading early for convenience, or switch to the standard calendar date observed by most places?

options.text: Read on the 14th like most places.
Read early for convenience of outlying farmers.

title: All-women quorum for public reading
vignette: A women's book-club wants to perform the holiday scroll reading on its own, saying the blessing aloud. Ten women would be present, but no men. Is such a reading considered fully public, or must they join a mixed gathering?

options.text: Yes; women count for Megillah reading.
No; they should hear it with a men's quorum.

title: Working on Purim
vignette: Some say ordinary labor is discouraged on Purim morning. A shopkeeper wants to open briefly before the festivities.

options.text: Open the shop; work is permitted.
Keep it closed out of respect for the holiday.

title: Gifts vs. feast on the holiday budget
vignette: Funds are tight. Community members debate whether to spend more on food for the festive meal or on care-packages sent to neighbors and those in need. Which priority comes first when you can't do both generously?

options.text: Moderate drinking only; avoid excess.
Drink freely to reach a joyful state.

title: Pause study for annual reading?
vignette: A group of scholars is immersed in intensive research. The public reading of the annual scroll is about to begin. Must they pause their study to listen, or may they keep working because learning never stops?

options.text: Focus on gifts to the poor first.
Spend on the meal; joy is central.

title: Which day should travelers observe?
vignette: A city that normally celebrates the festival one day later welcomes visitors from towns that celebrate on the earlier day. While staying overnight, should the guests observe both days to be safe, or just follow the local date?

options.text: Yes; translation fulfils the obligation.
No; it must be in Hebrew.

title: Read from a worn scroll?
vignette: The community's scroll has several faded letters. A replacement won't arrive in time. Can they still read from the imperfect copy, or must they wait until a fully legible scroll is available?

options.text: Yes; everyone must pause to hear it.
They may continue studying instead.

title: Children's noise during the reading
vignette: Kids occasionally shout during the public recitation, causing listeners to miss words. Should the reader stop and repeat the missed lines once it's quiet, or continue without repeating?

options.text: Observe both days to be safe.
Keep only the day of the place you're in.

title: Acting out the Megillah drama
vignette: Youth plan a dramatic reenactment of the Purim story. Elders fear it trivializes the text.

options.text: Allow the play; it engages people.
Discourage it; keep the reading solemn.

title: Reading from a damaged scroll
vignette: The community's Megillah has a few worn letters. A new one won't arrive in time. Can they read from the damaged scroll?

options.text: Yes if most letters remain legible.
No; wait until a proper scroll is available.

title: Interruptions during the reading
vignette: Children occasionally make noise during Megillah reading causing listeners to miss words.

options.text: Repeat the missed verses after quieting them.
Proceed without repetition.

title: Combining megillah with other scrolls
vignette: A printer wants to bind the Megillah together with other writings for convenience. Some say it diminishes its sanctity.

options.text: Bind it separately to honor it.
Combination is fine and saves money.

title: Reader sits vs. stands
vignette: The designated reader is exhausted and prefers to sit while reciting. Others feel standing shows proper respect. Should the reading be done standing despite discomfort, or is sitting acceptable?

options.text: Read standing despite discomfort.
Sitting is acceptable if needed.

title: Microphone for large hall
vignette: In a spacious venue, only a microphone will let everyone hear. Some argue electronic amplification changes the nature of hearing a live reading. Should they use the sound system or rely solely on the unaided human voice?

options.text: Use the microphone so all can hear.
Avoid; each must hear the natural voice.

title: Reading again for latecomers
vignette: After finishing, a few people arrive who missed the Megillah entirely. Should the reader repeat it just for them?

options.text: Yes; reread so they fulfil the duty.
No; they must find another reading elsewhere.
